title: Unclear error message recommending `spack rm repo`
body:
I am encountering this error message:

```
$ spack compilers
==> Warning: Failed to initialize repository at '$spack/var/spack/repos/eschnett'.
  No repo.yaml found in '$spack/var/spack/repos/eschnett'
  To remove the bad repository, run this command:
      spack repo rm $spack/var/spack/repos/eschnett
==> Available compilers
==> Error: /home/eschnett/.spack/compilers.yaml:2: [{'compiler': {'modules': [], 'operating_system': 'centos7', 'paths': {'cc': '/usr/local/bin/gcc', 'cxx': '/usr/local/bin/g++', 'f77': '/usr/local/bin/gfortran', 'fc': '/usr/local/bin/gfortran'}, 'spec': 'gcc@5.2.0'}}, {'compiler': {'modules': [], 'operating_system': 'centos7', 'paths': {'cc': '/usr/bin/gcc', 'cxx': '/usr/bin/g++', 'f77': '/usr/bin/gfortran', 'fc': '/usr/bin/gfortran'}, 'spec': 'gcc@4.8.5'}}, {'compiler': {'modules': [], 'operating_system': 'centos7', 'paths': {'cc': '/opt/intel/bin/icc', 'cxx': '/opt/intel/bin/icpc', 'f77': '/opt/intel/bin/ifort', 'fc': '/opt/intel/bin/ifort'}, 'spec': 'intel@16.0.3'}}, {'compiler': {'modules': [], 'operating_system': 'centos7', 'paths': {'cc': '/home/eschnett/src/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-5.2.0/gcc-6.2.0-4cisidsr6udphv5z4yrf5uini5spao4f/bin/gcc', 'cxx': '/home/eschnett/src/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-5.2.0/gcc-6.2.0-4cisidsr6udphv5z4yrf5uini5spao4f/bin/g++', 'f77': '/home/eschnett/src/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-5.2.0/gcc-6.2.0-4cisidsr6udphv5z4yrf5uini5spao4f/bin/gfortran', 'fc': '/home/eschnett/src/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-5.2.0/gcc-6.2.0-4cisidsr6udphv5z4yrf5uini5spao4f/bin/gfortran'}, 'spec': 'gcc@6.2.0-spack'}}] is not of type 'object'
```

I don't know how to interpret the suggestion `spack repo rm $spack/var/spack/repos/eschnett`, in particular the term `$spack` there. I tried:
- using this command verbatim
- leaving out the `$spack/` prefix
- using `$(pwd)` as value for `$spack`
- putting the path in quotes to protect the `$` sign
  but each time I only receive the same error message again.

I don't think that using an unquoted `$` sign in a suggested command is a good idea. Please augment the error message to state what `spack` is supposed to be, or -- better yet -- calculate the value of `spack`, and output it.
